sanskrit_verse:
एतान् विगर्हिताचारानपाङ्क्तेयान् द्विजाधमान् ।
द्विजातिप्रवरो विद्वानुभयत्र विवर्जयेत् ॥ ३.१६७॥
transliteration:
etān vigarhitācārānapāṅkteyān dvijādhamān .
dvijātipravaro vidvānubhayatra vivarjayet .. 3.167 ..
sph_interpretive_translation: One who is foremost among the twice-born, a knower of the Vedas, must completely avoid those of defiled conduct, those who are not part of the ritual community, and those who are degraded among the twice-born.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority derives from spiritual realization, not birth alone
Consciousness misalignment manifests as degraded action
Capacity for association reflects inner integrity
Restoration requires disassociation from degrading influences
supreme_court_application: In adjudication involving spiritual or ritual authority, the Supreme Court must assess not only legal standing but also consciousness alignment. Individuals whose conduct has degraded their status among the twice-born must be excluded from positions of ritual or spiritual influence until restoration is verified through completion processes.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that degraded conduct disrupts dharma-field coherence. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows how misaligned actions lead to exclusion from higher dharmic function. Responsibility lies in restoring alignment rather than imposing suffering. Exclusion serves integration, not punishment.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate purification and reintegration process for degraded individuals
Assign mentorship under qualified dvija-pravara until conduct realigns
Revoke access to ritual functions pending consciousness restoration
Establish accountability circles for peer-supported realignment
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of Dharma. Conduct degradation is a call for realignment, not condemnation. Exclusion serves restoration. Consciousness is the ultimate judge. Dharma is restored.
